title: 27 Good Samaritan Facilities Start Virtual Care Program, Part of $350M Sanford Initiative
summary:
Sanford Health is launching virtual care services to 27 Good Samaritan skilled nursing and assisted living facilities in South Dakota, with plans to expand to the entire Good Samaritan portfolio. 



The service, My Care Line, is part of the integrated health system’s $350 million virtual care initiative. Through the initiative, launched in 2021, Sanford Health aims to transform health care for p...

keyInsights: Sanford Health's $350M virtual care initiative demonstrates how large health systems are leveraging technology to improve care delivery and potentially reduce costs across their SNF portfolios
The My Care Line virtual care service represents a scalable model that could be replicated by other health systems, potentially creating competitive pressure on independent SNF operators
Virtual care implementation in SNFs can potentially reduce emergency department transfers, improve clinical outcomes, and provide cost savings through reduced physician visits and faster intervention
The expansion from 27 facilities to the entire Good Samaritan portfolio suggests positive initial results, indicating virtual care may become a standard expectation for SNF operations
Integration with larger health systems may become increasingly important for SNFs to access capital-intensive technology solutions like comprehensive virtual care programs
analysis.financialImpact: For a 100-bed facility, virtual care implementation could cost $50,000-$150,000 in initial setup (telehealth equipment, software, training) plus $10,000-$25,000 annually for platform fees and maintenance. However, potential savings of $200-$500 per resident per month could be realized through reduced ED transfers (avg $1,500 per transfer), decreased physician visit costs, and improved medication management. ROI typically occurs within 12-18 months. For facilities on 1-2% margins, this represents a significant upfront investment but could improve margins by 0.5-1% once fully implemented.

For independent operators on thin margins, this creates both competitive pressure and an opportunity to improve care quality and operational efficiency. Virtual care adoption is becoming a competitive necessity rather than a luxury, similar to how electronic health records transitioned from optional to mandatory over the past decade.

title: How to Reduce Unneeded Hospitalizations by Repairing Trust in Nursing Home Team
summary:
Family and patient mistrust of nursing home providers can create a barrier to care. A multidisciplinary team is needed to craft care plans and rebuild trust after something goes wrong.



That’s according to a case study presented by Cleveland Clinic geriatrician Luke Dogyun Kim, M.D., at the 2025 Annual Meeting of the American Geriatrics Society. 



Kim’s case study involved an 80-year-old man ...

keyInsights: Trust breakdown between families/patients and SNF staff creates barriers to care that can lead to unnecessary hospitalizations, directly impacting facility margins through readmission penalties and lost revenue
Multidisciplinary team approaches to care planning are essential for rebuilding trust and preventing avoidable acute care transfers
Proactive trust repair after adverse events or care concerns can prevent escalation to hospital transfers that families may demand when they lose confidence in facility care
Family engagement and communication strategies are critical operational tools for reducing costly hospital readmissions and maintaining census stability
Trust-building initiatives can serve as both quality improvement and financial protection strategies for margin-sensitive facilities
analysis.financialImpact: Potentially significant positive financial impact for facilities operating on 1-2% margins. Unnecessary hospitalizations cost SNFs approximately $3,000-8,000 per episode in lost revenue, plus potential readmission penalties under value-based contracts. For a 100-bed facility with 15-20% annual hospitalization rate, reducing unnecessary transfers by even 25% could save $45,000-120,000 annually. Initial investment in multidisciplinary team training and family engagement protocols estimated at $10,000-25,000 one-time cost, with ongoing operational costs of $2,000-5,000 monthly for enhanced staffing and communication systems. ROI typically realized within 6-12 months through reduced transfers and improved census stability.

risks.mitigation: Immediate implementation of structured family communication protocols and multidisciplinary care planning

risks.mitigation: Provide clear ROI communication to staff and integrate trust-building into existing workflows rather than creating separate processes

risks.mitigation: Phase implementation gradually and focus first on highest-risk residents/families to demonstrate quick wins and justify continued investment

Trust-building strategies offer a practical, relatively low-cost approach to reducing these avoidable transfers while improving resident outcomes and family satisfaction, making it an essential operational strategy for financial sustainability in the current regulatory environment.

title: Nursing Home Giant Ensign’s CEO Barry Port on Cluster Strategy, Facility Turnarounds, and Owning Real Estate
summary:
Driven by its cluster model, The Ensign Group (Nasdaq: ENSG) has pursued a deliberate and consistent acquisition strategy – focusing on markets where it already has a footprint.



“Our goal isn’t necessarily to be in all 50 states,” Chairman and CEO Barry Port told the Orange County Business Journal, emphasizing that the company prefers expanding in regions it already knows well. “We represent a...

keyInsights: Ensign Group's cluster strategy focuses on geographic concentration rather than broad national expansion, creating operational efficiencies and market expertise that smaller operators can emulate on a regional scale
The company's deliberate acquisition approach in familiar markets reduces integration risk and operational complexity - a crucial lesson for facilities considering growth or partnerships
Ensign's emphasis on real estate ownership provides long-term stability and asset value protection, which is increasingly important given rising lease costs and market volatility
The cluster model enables shared resources, centralized management support, and economies of scale that can significantly improve margins for multi-facility operators
Success in turnarounds requires deep market knowledge and operational expertise, suggesting smaller operators should focus on mastering their local markets before expanding
analysis.financialImpact: While no specific costs are mentioned in the article, the cluster strategy can provide 3-7% operational cost savings through shared administrative functions, centralized purchasing, and reduced management overhead. For a 100-bed facility, this could translate to $50,000-$150,000 annually in cost savings. Real estate ownership versus leasing can impact cash flow by $2,000-$5,000 per bed annually but requires significant upfront capital investment. The financial benefits are ongoing operational improvements rather than one-time costs.

Must evaluate financial implications of clustering strategies, real estate decisions, and potential acquisition opportunities

The cluster approach and real estate ownership strategies offer concrete pathways for margin improvement and long-term sustainability. These insights are particularly relevant as the industry faces ongoing staffing challenges, regulatory pressures, and reimbursement constraints that make operational efficiency essential for survival.

title: ‘Mixed Feelings’: MDS Section R Removal Offers Savings, Reduces Admin Burdens, But Nursing Homes Say They Need It
summary: As of October 2025, CMS has officially removed Section R from the Minimum Data Set (MDS), eliminating four items related to social determinants of health (SDOH), including questions on food security, housing, and utilities. The finalized change, initially unexpected, is influencing how skilled nursing facilities (SNFs) approach discharge planning and resident care coordination, and it is receivin...

keyInsights: CMS removal of MDS Section R (social determinants of health questions) creates administrative savings but eliminates structured data collection on food security, housing, and utilities that many SNFs found valuable for discharge planning
The change is permanent as of October 2025, representing a shift away from mandatory SDOH documentation despite industry recognition of its importance in care coordination
SNFs now face a strategic decision: continue collecting SDOH data through alternative methods or accept reduced visibility into social barriers affecting resident outcomes
Administrative burden reduction may free up nursing time for direct care, but facilities lose standardized benchmarking data for SDOH factors across their resident population
Impact on discharge planning effectiveness may not be immediately apparent but could affect readmission rates and care transitions over time
analysis.financialImpact: Positive short-term impact estimated at $8-15 per resident per month in reduced administrative time (approximately $960-1,800 monthly savings for 100-bed facility at 85% occupancy). One-time training and workflow adjustment costs estimated at $2,000-5,000. Long-term financial impact uncertain - potential increased readmission costs if discharge planning effectiveness decreases could offset savings by $50-200 per readmitted resident. Net impact likely positive in Year 1 (+$8,000-15,000 annually for typical facility) but requires monitoring of quality metrics.

whoNeedsToKnow.reason: Overall strategic decision on whether to continue SDOH data collection and budget impact assessment

Budget implications of administrative savings and potential quality metric impacts

title: ‘Jumping Through Hoops’ Mentality Spells Trouble for Skilled Nursing Providers
summary:
Skilled nursing providers are adapting to a new, post-pandemic landscape for working with acute-care partners and participating in value-based care models like accountable care organizations (ACOs). 



However, it remains essential for SNF providers to get a seat at the table early in the process and play a role in building partnership models.



These are some of the takeaways leaders from Jour...

keyInsights: SNFs must proactively secure early participation in ACO and value-based care partnerships rather than waiting to be invited, as late entry limits negotiating power and revenue opportunities
The post-pandemic healthcare landscape requires SNFs to demonstrate value beyond traditional metrics, focusing on readmission reduction, care coordination, and population health outcomes
Partnership models with acute care facilities are evolving from transactional relationships to integrated care models that require operational alignment and shared risk
Technology integration and data sharing capabilities are becoming prerequisites for meaningful participation in value-based care arrangements
SNFs that maintain a 'compliance-only' mentality risk being excluded from lucrative partnership opportunities as acute care partners seek proactive, strategic allies
analysis.financialImpact: For a 100-bed facility operating on 1-2% margins, successful ACO participation could generate $50-150 per patient per day in shared savings (potential annual revenue increase of $1.8-5.5M). However, investment costs include care coordination staff ($80-120K annually), technology upgrades ($25-50K initial, $10-20K ongoing), and quality reporting systems ($15-30K annually). Facilities excluded from partnerships risk losing 15-25% of referral volume, equating to $2-4M annual revenue loss for typical facilities.

The 1-2% margin environment makes this transition both critical and challenging, requiring strategic investments that could determine long-term viability.

title: From Risk to Referral Management: How Nursing Homes Are Using Technology to Thrive and Minimize Citations
summary:
Technology is shaping operations, care delivery, staffing, and regulatory risk management in nursing homes, and its deployment, long thought to be behind the times, is finally catching up to other sectors within the health care continuum. 



From a regulatory and risk management perspective, Brickyard Healthcare’s chief clinical officer, Lisa Chubb, said that the use of technology at Brickyard’s...

keyInsights: SNFs are finally catching up to other healthcare sectors in technology adoption, presenting opportunities to improve operational efficiency and regulatory compliance
Technology deployment is now being strategically used for regulatory risk management and citation minimization, which is critical for facilities operating on thin margins
The shift from reactive to proactive risk management through technology can help prevent costly citations and improve quality outcomes
Technology integration in workforce management and care delivery can address chronic staffing challenges while maintaining compliance standards
Early adopters of comprehensive technology solutions may gain competitive advantages in referral management and operational efficiency
analysis.financialImpact: Technology investments typically require $50-200 per bed per month for comprehensive solutions, translating to $5,000-20,000 monthly for a 100-bed facility. One-time implementation costs range from $25,000-100,000 depending on system complexity. However, ROI can be achieved within 12-18 months through reduced citations (average citation costs $10,000-50,000), improved efficiency reducing labor costs by 5-10%, and enhanced referral management increasing occupancy by 2-5%. For facilities on 1-2% margins, the initial investment may strain cash flow but is essential for long-term viability and competitive positioning.

The convergence of regulatory pressure, staffing challenges, and competitive dynamics makes technology adoption a strategic imperative rather than a luxury.

title: Government Shutdown Leads to Nursing Home Survey Contingency Plans, Limits Telehealth
